The cash flow additivity principle refers to the fact that present value of any stream
of cash flows equals the sum of the present values of the cash flows. There are different
applications of this principle in time value of money problems. If we have two series
of cash flows, the sum of the present values of the two series is the same as the present
values of the two series taken together, adding cash flows that will be paid at the same
point in time. We can also divide up a series of cash flows any way we like, and the
present value of the “pieces” will equal the present value of the original series.
